citation.article-title: Taxonomic study of bacteria isolated from Lebanese spring waters: proposal for Pseudomonas cedrella sp. nov. and P. orientalis sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Pseudomonas cedrella sp. nov.
Pseudomonas cedrella (ced. re.'lla M. L. fem. gen. n. cedrella, of cedar, the characteristic tree of Lebanon, the country from which isolates were taken)
The type strain is CFML 96-198T, and has been deposited in the Collection of the lnstitut Pasteur as CIP 105541T .
The description is based on data for the following strains: CFML 96-198T (= CIP 105541T ), CFML 96-214, CFML 96-179, CFML 96-176, CFML 96-209, CFML 96-215, CFML 96-213, CFML 96-187, and CFML 96-203.
The G+C content of the DNA is 59 to 60 mol%.
Cell and colonial characteristics.
Cells are Gram-negative, asporogenous and rod-shaped, motile by means of a single polar flagellum (figure 1).
Colonies are smooth on nutrient agar, circular, nonpigmented, and nonhemolytic when grown on blood agar.
Biochemical and physiological characteristics.
All strains of P. cedrella produce the fluorescent pigment on King B medium as well as on SI medium [18].
Arginine dihydrolase, catalase, and oxidase are also produced.
Significant growth is observed only at low salt concentrations (0.8%), but not at the following upper salinities tested: 5 and 7%.
Strains grow at 4°C.
They produce levan from sucrose.
Strains fail to grow at 41°C.
Strains lack DNase and lecithinase.
Strains do not produce coagulase or elastase.
Lysine and ornithine are not decarboxylated.
No phenazine pigments are produced on King A medium.
The species does not form indole from tryptophan.
No phenylalanine desaminase activity is observed.
Fibrinolysin, acetoin, and 2,3,5-triphenyltetrazolium chloride test negative.
Assimilation of carbon compounds.

All strains utilize the following substrates as carbon and energy sources (Biotype-100 system, BioMerieux, 69280 Marcy-l'Etoile, France): α-D(+) glucose, β-D(+) fructose, D(+) galactose, D(+) trehalose, D(+) mannose, D(-) ribose, L(+) arabinose, D(+) xylose, D-lyxose, i-erythritol, D-saccharate, mucate, L(-) malate, trans-aconitate, D-glucuronate, D-galacturonate, 2-keto-D- gluconate, N-acetyl-D-glucosamine, protocatechuate, (-) quinate, betain, putrescine, caprate, caprylate, succinate, fumarate, glutarate, DL-glycerate, D-glucosamine, 3-hydroxybutyrate, D-alanine, malonate, L-tyrosine, α-ketoglutarate.

No strains use the following substrates as sole carbon and energy sources: α-D(+) melibiose, sucrose, D(+) raffinose, maltotriose, maltose, α-lactose, lactulose, 1-O-methyl-β-galactopyranoside, 1-0-metyhl-α-galactopyranoside, D(+) cellobiose, β-gentiobiose, 1-O-methyl-β-D-glucopyranoside, palatinose, α-L(-) fucose, D(+) melezitose, dulcitol, D-tagatose, maltitol, D(+) turanose, 1-O-methyl-α-D-glucopyranoside, 3-0methyl- D-glucopyranose, L(+) tartrate, tricarballylate, 5-keto-D-gluconate, phenylacetate, gentisate, 3-hydroxybenzoate, benzoate, 3-phenylpropionate, m-coumarate, trigonelline, histamine, itaconate.
Enzymatic tests (APIZYM system, biomerieux).
The following enzymatic activities have been recorded: esterase-lipase (C8), trypsine.
No enzymatic activity has been observed for the following enzymes: lipase (C14), β-glucosidase.
